parvati_story.definition: Parvati is the Hindu goddess of love, fertility, devotion, and power. She is the consort of Lord Shiva and represents Shakti, the divine feminine energy.

appearance: Graceful form adorned with ornaments and silk garments.
Often depicted with Lord Shiva and their sons Ganesha and Kartikeya.
Carries lotus, trident, and sometimes a mirror.
symbols: Lion or tiger as vehicle – courage and strength.

major_legends.name: Birth and Marriage to Shiva
major_legends.summary: Born as the daughter of King Himavan, Parvati performed severe penance to win Lord Shiva as her husband, symbolizing devotion and perseverance.

major_legends.name: Incarnation as Durga
major_legends.summary: Parvati took the fierce form of Durga to destroy the demon Mahishasura, representing the triumph of good over evil.

major_legends.name: Incarnation as Kali
major_legends.summary: In her wrathful form, Parvati became Kali to annihilate demons, symbolizing ultimate power and destruction of ego.

major_legends.name: Mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya
major_legends.summary: Parvati created Ganesha from her body and gave birth to Kartikeya, both revered as divine sons.

symbolism: Represents Shakti – the dynamic energy of the universe.
Balances Shiva’s ascetic nature with nurturing energy.
forms_of_parvati: Meenakshi – Regional form worshipped in Tamil Nadu.

festivals.name: Navaratri
festivals.significance: Nine nights celebrating Parvati in her various forms.

festivals.name: Teej
festivals.significance: Festival for marital bliss and devotion to Shiva.

modern_relevance.spirituality: Symbol of inner strength and devotion.
